leftPanel.title: Time is Your Greatest Asset
paragraphs: Starting early gives compound interest decades to work its magic. The difference between starting at 25 vs. 35 is enormous.
Start at 25: Invest $200/month at 7% return = $525,000 by age 65
Start at 35: Invest $200/month at 7% return = $244,000 by age 65
Same monthly investment, 10 years earlier = more than DOUBLE the result!

highlightBox.text: ‚è∞ Every year you wait to start investing for retirement costs you thousands in potential growth!

layoutData.title: Your Retirement Toolkit
paragraphs: You have several tax-advantaged options for retirement savings. Understanding each helps you maximize your strategy.
bulletPoints: 401(k): Employer-sponsored. Pre-tax contributions, employer match (FREE money!), $23,000 limit in 2024
Traditional IRA: Tax-deductible contributions NOW, pay taxes when you withdraw in retirement
Roth IRA: Pay taxes NOW, withdrawals in retirement are completely TAX-FREE (great for young people)
Social Security: Government program, funded by payroll taxes. Provides baseline income in retirement

keyPoint.text: üí° Pro tip: If your employer offers a 401(k) match, ALWAYS contribute enough to get the full match‚Äîit's free money!

content.headerTitle: Traditional vs. Roth: When to Use Each

leftPanel.title: Traditional (401k or IRA)
paragraphs: How it works: Contribute pre-tax dollars now, pay taxes when you withdraw in retirement.
Best for: People who expect to be in a LOWER tax bracket in retirement than they are now.
Example: High earners in their peak earning years who will have lower income in retirement.

highlightBox.text: � Reduces your taxable income TODAY = lower current tax bill

leftPanel.title: A Framework for Saving
paragraphs: The 50/30/20 rule is a simple budgeting guideline that helps you allocate your after-tax income:
50% ‚Üí Needs: Housing, utilities, food, transportation, insurance, minimum payments
30% ‚Üí Wants: Entertainment, dining out, hobbies, subscriptions, upgrades
20% ‚Üí Savings & Investing: Emergency fund, retirement contributions, extra debt payments

highlightBox.text: � If you can put 20% toward savings/investing, you're building a strong financial foundation!

leftPanel.title: Free Money You Can't Ignore
paragraphs: Many employers offer to match your 401(k) contributions up to a certain percentage. This is essentially free money!
Example: Your employer matches 100% of contributions up to 4% of your salary.
If you earn $50,000 and contribute 4% ($2,000), your employer adds another $2,000 = $4,000 total!
That's an immediate 100% return on your investment‚Äîno other investment can guarantee that.

highlightBox.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Not contributing enough to get the full employer match is literally leaving free money on the table!

layoutData.title: Your Timeline Affects Your Strategy
paragraphs: How much time you have until retirement determines how much risk you can reasonably take with your investments.
bulletPoints: 40+ Years (Age 20-25): Can be aggressive (80-90% stocks). Plenty of time to recover from market dips.
25-40 Years (Age 25-40): Growth-focused with some stability. Gradually increase bonds (70-80% stocks).
10-25 Years (Age 40-55): Balanced approach. Protect gains while still growing (60-70% stocks).
Under 10 Years (Age 55+): Conservative. Prioritize preserving what you've built (40-50% stocks).

keyPoint.text: üîÑ Target-date funds automatically shift from aggressive to conservative as you approach retirement!

scenario.name: Micah's Smart Start at 22 in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Micah gets his first job at 22, earning $45,000/year. His employer offers a 401(k) with 4% match.
Micah contributes 6% of his salary ($2,700/year) to his 401(k). His employer matches 4% ($1,800/year). Total: $4,500/year going into retirement.
Result: Even if Micah never gets a raise and contributes the same amount for 43 years until age 65, at 7% average returns his 401(k) would grow to over $1.1 million!

scenario.name: Jordan Waits Until 32 in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Jordan earns the same as Micah and has the same employer match. But Jordan waits until age 32 to start contributing.
Jordan contributes the same $4,500/year ($2,700 + $1,800 match) for 33 years until retirement.
Result: At 7% average returns, Jordan's 401(k) grows to about $525,000‚Äîless than HALF of what Micah has, even though Jordan contributed for only 10 fewer years.
The cost of waiting: Those 10 extra years of compounding are worth over $575,000!

takeaways.title: Start Early
takeaways.description: Time is your greatest asset. Starting 10 years earlier can double your retirement savings through compounding.

takeaways.title: Get the Match
takeaways.description: Always contribute enough to get your full employer 401(k) match‚Äîit's free money with 100% instant return.

takeaways.title: Choose Your Tax Timing
takeaways.description: Young people often benefit from Roth accounts‚Äîpay taxes now while in a low bracket, enjoy tax-free growth.

takeaways.title: Adjust Risk to Time
takeaways.description: With decades until retirement, you can afford more stock exposure. Become more conservative as you approach 65.
